column2: CHAPTER XX
column3: CHAPTER twenty

column2: When he came into the New House, a few minutes later, he found his father sitting alone by the library fire.
column3: When he came into the New House, a few minutes later, he found his father sitting alone by the library fire.

column2: Bibbs went in and stood before him.
column3: Bibbs went in and stood before him.

column2: I'm cured, father, he said.
column3: I'm cured, father, he said.

column2: When do I go back to the shop?	When do I go back to the shop?
column3: true

column2: I'm ready."
column3: I'm ready."

column2: The desolate and grim old man did not relax.
column3: The desolate and grim old man did not relax.

column2: I was sittin' up to give you a last chance to say something like that.	I was sittin' up to give you a last chance to say something like that.
column3: true

column2: I reckon it's about time! I just wanted to see if you'd have manhood enough not to make me take you over there by the collar.
column3: I reckon it's about time! I just wanted to see if you'd have manhood enough not to make me take you over there by the collar.

column2: Last night I made up my mind I'd give you just one more day.
column3: Last night I made up my mind I'd give you just one more day.

column2: Well, you got to it before I did--pretty close to the eleventh hour!
column3: Well, you got to it before I did-pretty close to the eleventh hour!

column2: All right.
column3: All right.

column2: Start in to-morrow.
column3: Start in to morrow.

column2: It's the first o' the month.
column3: It's the first o' the month.

column2: Think you can get up in time?"
column3: Think you can get up in time?"

column2: Six o'clock, Bibbs responded, briskly.
column3: Six o'clock, Bibbs responded, briskly.

column2: And I want to tell you--I'm going in a 'cheerful spirit.' As you said, I'll go and I'll 'like it'!
column3: And I want to tell you-I'm going in a 'cheerful spirit.' As you said, I'll go and I'll 'like it'!

column2: That's YOUR lookout! his father grunted.
column3: That's YOUR lookout! his father grunted.

column2: They'll put you back on the clippin'-machine.	They'll put you back on the clippin'-machine.
column3: true

column2: You get nine dollars a week."
column3: You get nine dollars a week."

column2: More than I'm worth, too, said Bibbs, cheerily.
column3: More than I'm worth, too, said Bibbs, cheerily.

column2: That reminds me, I didn't mean YOU by 'Midas' in that nonsense I'd been writing.	That reminds me, I didn't mean YOU by 'Midas' in that nonsense I'd been writing.
column3: true

column2: I meant--"
column3: I meant-"

column2: Makes a hell of a lot o' difference what you meant!
column3: Makes a hell of a lot o' difference what you meant!

column2: I just wanted you to know.	I just wanted you to know.
column3: true

column2: Good night, father."
column3: Good night, father."

column2: G'night!
column3: G'night!

column2: The sound of the young man's footsteps ascending the stairs became inaudible, and the house was quiet.
column3: The sound of the young man's footsteps ascending the stairs became inaudible, and the house was quiet.

column2: But presently, as Sheridan sat staring angrily at the fire, the shuffling of a pair of slippers could be heard descending, and Mrs. Sheridan made her appearance, her oblique expression and the state of her toilette being those of a person who, after trying unsuccessfully to sleep on one side, has got up to look for burglars.
column3: But presently, as Sheridan sat staring angrily at the fire, the shuffling of a pair of slippers could be heard descending, and mrs Sheridan made her appearance, her oblique expression and the state of her toilette being those of a person who, after trying unsuccessfully to sleep on one side, has got up to look for burglars.

column2: Papa! she exclaimed, drowsily.
column3: Papa! she exclaimed, drowsily.

column2: Why'n't you go to bed?	Why'n't you go to bed?
column3: true

column2: It must be goin' on 'leven o'clock!"
column3: It must be goin' on 'leven o'clock!"

column2: She yawned, and seated herself near him, stretching out her hands to the fire.
column3: She yawned, and seated herself near him, stretching out her hands to the fire.

column2: What's the matter? she asked, sleep and anxiety striving sluggishly with each other in her voice.
column3: What's the matter? she asked, sleep and anxiety striving sluggishly with each other in her voice.

column2: I knew you were worried all dinner-time.	I knew you were worried all dinner time.
column3: true

column2: You got something new on your mind besides Jim's bein' taken away like he was.
column3: You got something new on your mind besides Jim's bein' taken away like he was.

column2: What's worryin' you now, papa?"
column3: What's worryin' you now, papa?"

column2: Nothin'.
column3: Nothin'.

column2: She jeered feebly.
column3: She jeered feebly.

column2: N' tell ME that!	n' tell m e that!
column3: false

column2: You sat up to see Bibbs, didn't you?"
column3: You sat up to see Bibbs, didn't you?"

column2: He starts in at the shop again to-morrow morning, said Sheridan.
column3: He starts in at the shop again to morrow morning, said Sheridan.

column2: Just the same as he did before?
column3: Just the same as he did before?

column2: Just pre-CISELY!
column3: Just pre c i s e l y!

column2: How--how long you goin' to keep him at it, papa? she asked, timidly.
column3: How-how long you goin' to keep him at it, papa? she asked, timidly.

column2: Until he KNOWS something!
column3: Until he KNOWS something!

column2: The unhappy man struck his palms together, then got to his feet and began to pace the room, as was his wont when he talked.
column3: The unhappy man struck his palms together, then got to his feet and began to pace the room, as was his wont when he talked.

column2: He'll go back to the machine he couldn't learn to tend properly in the six months he was there, and he'll stick to it till he DOES learn it!	He'll go back to the machine he couldn't learn to tend properly in the six months he was there, and he'll stick to it till he DOES learn it!
column3: true

column2: Do you suppose that lummix ever asked himself WHY I want him to learn it?
column3: Do you suppose that lummix ever asked himself WHY I want him to learn it?

column2: No!
column3: No!

column2: And I ain't a-goin' to tell him, either!
column3: And I ain't a goin' to tell him, either!

column2: When he went there I had 'em set him on the simplest machine we got--and he stuck there!
column3: When he went there I had 'em set him on the simplest machine we got-and he stuck there!

column2: How much prospect would there be of his learnin' to run the whole business if he can't run the easiest machine in it?
column3: How much prospect would there be of his learnin' to run the whole business if he can't run the easiest machine in it?

column2: I sent him there to make him THOROUGH.
column3: I sent him there to make him THOROUGH.

column2: And what happened?
column3: And what happened?

column2: He didn't LIKE it!
column3: He didn't LIKE it!

column2: That boy's whole life, there's been a settin' up o' something mulish that's against everything I want him to do.
column3: That boy's whole life, there's been a settin' up o' something mulish that's against everything I want him to do.

column2: I don't know what it is, but it's got to be worked out of him.
column3: I don't know what it is, but it's got to be worked out of him.

column2: Now, labor ain't any more a simple question than what it was when we were young.
column3: Now, labor ain't any more a simple question than what it was when we were young.

column2: My idea is that, outside o' union troubles, the man that can manage workin'-men is the man that's been one himself. Well, I set Bibbs to learn the men and to learn the business, and HE set himself to balk on the first job!
column3: My idea is that, outside o' union troubles, the man that can manage workin'-men is the man that's been one himself. Well, I set Bibbs to learn the men and to learn the business, and HE set himself to balk on the first job!

column2: That's what he did, and the balk's lasted close on to three years.
column3: That's what he did, and the balk's lasted close on to three years.

column2: If he balks again I'm just done with him!
column3: If he balks again I'm just done with him!

column2: Sometimes I feel like I was pretty near done with everything, anyhow!"
column3: Sometimes I feel like I was pretty near done with everything, anyhow!"

column2: I knew there was something else, said Mrs. Sheridan, blinking over a yawn.
column3: I knew there was something else, said mrs Sheridan, blinking over a yawn.

column2: You better let it go till to-morrow and get to bed now--'less you'll tell me?
column3: You better let it go till to morrow and get to bed now-'less you'll tell me?

column2: Suppose something happened to Roscoe, he said.
column3: Suppose something happened to Roscoe, he said.

column2: THEN what'd I have to look forward to?	THEN what'd I have to look forward to?
column3: true

column2: THEN what could I depend on to hold things together?
column3: THEN what could I depend on to hold things together?

column2: A lummix!
column3: A lummix!

column2: A lummix that hasn't learned how to push a strip o' zinc along a groove!"
column3: A lummix that hasn't learned how to push a strip o' zinc along a groove!"

column2: Roscoe? she yawned.
column3: Roscoe? she yawned.

column2: You needn't worry about Roscoe, papa.	You needn't worry about Roscoe, papa.
column3: true

column2: He's the strongest child we had.
column3: He's the strongest child we had.

column2: I never did know anybody keep better health than he does.
column3: I never did know anybody keep better health than he does.

column2: I don't believe he's even had a cold in five years.
column3: I don't believe he's even had a cold in five years.

column2: You better go up to bed, papa."
column3: You better go up to bed, papa."

column2: Suppose something DID happen to him, though.	Suppose something DID happen to him, though.
column3: false

column2: You don't know what it means, keepin' property together these days--just keepin' it ALIVE, let alone makin' it grow the way I do.
column3: You don't know what it means, keepin' property together these days-just keepin' it ALIVE, let alone makin' it grow the way I do.

column2: I've seen too many estates hacked away in chunks, big and little.
column3: I've seen too many estates hacked away in chunks, big and little.

column2: I tell you when a man dies the wolves come out o' the woods, pack after pack, to see what they can tear off for themselves; and if that dead man's chuldern ain't on the job, night and day, everything he built'll get carried off.
column3: I tell you when a man dies the wolves come out o' the woods, pack after pack, to see what they can tear off for themselves; and if that dead man's chuldern ain't on the job, night and day, everything he built'll get carried off.

column2: Carried off?
column3: Carried off?

column2: I've seen a big fortune behave like an ash-barrel in a cyclone--there wasn't even a dust-heap left to tell where it stood!
column3: I've seen a big fortune behave like an ash barrel in a cyclone-there wasn't even a dust heap left to tell where it stood!

column2: I've seen it, time and again. My Lord! when I think o' such things comin' to ME!
column3: I've seen it, time and again. My Lord! when I think o' such things comin' to m e!

column2: It don't seem like I deserved it--no man ever tried harder to raise his boys right than I have.
column3: It don't seem like I deserved it-no man ever tried harder to raise his boys right than I have.

column2: I planned and planned and planned how to bring 'em up to be guards to drive the wolves off, and how to be builders to build, and build bigger.
column3: I planned and planned and planned how to bring 'em up to be guards to drive the wolves off, and how to be builders to build, and build bigger.

column2: I tell you this business life is no fool's job nowadays--a man's got to have eyes in the back of his head.
column3: I tell you this business life is no fool's job nowadays-a man's got to have eyes in the back of his head.

column2: You hear talk, sometimes, 'd make you think the millennium had come--but right the next breath you'll hear somebody hollerin' about 'the great unrest.' You BET there's a 'great unrest'!
column3: You hear talk, sometimes, 'd make you think the millennium had come-but right the next breath you'll hear somebody hollerin' about 'the great unrest.' You BET there's a 'great unrest'!

column2: There ain't any man alive smart enough to see what it's goin' to do to us in the end, nor what day it's got set to bust loose, but it's frothin' and bubblin' in the boiler.
column3: There ain't any man alive smart enough to see what it's goin' to do to us in the end, nor what day it's got set to bust loose, but it's frothin' and bubblin' in the boiler.

column2: This country's been fillin' up with it from all over the world for a good many years, and the old camp-meetin' days are dead and done with.
column3: This country's been fillin' up with it from all over the world for a good many years, and the old camp meetin' days are dead and done with.

column2: Church ain't what it used to be.
column3: Church ain't what it used to be.

column2: Nothin's what it used to be--everything's turned up from the bottom, and the growth is so big the roots stick out in the air.
column3: Nothin's what it used to be-everything's turned up from the bottom, and the growth is so big the roots stick out in the air.

column2: There's an awful ruction goin' on, and you got to keep hoppin' if you're goin' to keep your balance on the top of it.
column3: There's an awful ruction goin' on, and you got to keep hoppin' if you're goin' to keep your balance on the top of it.

column2: And the schemers!
column3: And the schemers!

column2: They run like bugs on the bottom of a board--after any piece o' money they hear is loose.
column3: They run like bugs on the bottom of a board-after any piece o' money they hear is loose.

column2: Fool schemes and crooked schemes; the fool ones are the most and the worst!
column3: Fool schemes and crooked schemes; the fool ones are the most and the worst!

column2: You got to FIGHT to keep your money after you've made it.
column3: You got to FIGHT to keep your money after you've made it.

column2: And the woods are full o' mighty industrious men that's got only one motto: 'Get the other fellow's money before he gets yours!' And when a man's built as I have, when he's built good and strong, and made good things grow and prosper--THOSE are the fellows that lay for the chance to slide in and sneak the benefit of it and put their names to it!
column3: And the woods are full o' mighty industrious men that's got only one motto: 'Get the other fellow's money before he gets yours!' And when a man's built as I have, when he's built good and strong, and made good things grow and prosper-THOSE are the fellows that lay for the chance to slide in and sneak the benefit of it and put their names to it!

column2: And what's the use of my havin' ever been born, if such a thing as that is goin' to happen?
column3: And what's the use of my havin' ever been born, if such a thing as that is goin' to happen?

column2: What's the use of my havin' worked my life and soul into my business, if it's all goin' to be dispersed and scattered soon as I'm in the ground?"
column3: What's the use of my havin' worked my life and soul into my business, if it's all goin' to be dispersed and scattered soon as I'm in the ground?"

column2: He strode up and down the long room, gesticulating--little regarding the troubled and drowsy figure by the fireside.
column3: He strode up and down the long room, gesticulating-little regarding the troubled and drowsy figure by the fireside.

column2: His throat rumbled thunderously; the words came with stormy bitterness.
column3: His throat rumbled thunderously; the words came with stormy bitterness.

column2: You think this is a time for young men to be lyin' on beds of ease?	You think this is a time for young men to be lyin' on beds of ease?
column3: true

column2: I tell you there never was such a time before; there never was such opportunity.
column3: I tell you there never was such a time before; there never was such opportunity.

column2: The sluggard is despoiled while he sleeps--yes, by George! if a man lays down they'll eat him before he wakes!--but the live man can build straight up till he touches the sky!
column3: The sluggard is despoiled while he sleeps-yes, by George! if a man lays down they'll eat him before he wakes!--but the live man can build straight up till he touches the sky!

column2: This is the business man's day; it used to be the soldier's day and the statesman's day, but this is OURS!
column3: This is the business man's day; it used to be the soldier's day and the statesman's day, but this is OURS!

column2: And it ain't a Sunday to go fishin'--it's turmoil!
column3: And it ain't a Sunday to go fishin'--it's turmoil!

column2: turmoil!--and you got to go out and live it and breathe it and MAKE it yourself, or you'll only be a dead man walkin' around dreamin' you're alive.
column3: turmoil!--and you got to go out and live it and breathe it and MAKE it yourself, or you'll only be a dead man walkin' around dreamin' you're alive.

column2: And that's what my son Bibbs has been doin' all his life, and what he'd rather do now than go out and do his part by me.
column3: And that's what my son Bibbs has been doin' all his life, and what he'd rather do now than go out and do his part by me.

column2: And if anything happens to Roscoe--"
column3: And if anything happens to Roscoe-"

column2: Oh, do stop worryin' over such nonsense, Mrs. Sheridan interrupted, irritated into sharp wakefulness for the moment.
column3: Oh, do stop worryin' over such nonsense, mrs Sheridan interrupted, irritated into sharp wakefulness for the moment.

column2: There isn't anything goin' to happen to Roscoe, and you're just tormentin' yourself about nothin'.	There isn't anything goin' to happen to Roscoe, and you're just tormentin' yourself about nothin'.
column3: false

column2: Aren't you EVER goin' to bed?"
column3: Aren't you EVER goin' to bed?"

column2: Sheridan halted.
column3: Sheridan halted.

column2: All right, mamma, he said, with a vast sigh.
column3: All right, mamma, he said, with a vast sigh.

column2: Let's go up. And he snapped off the electric light, leaving only the rosy glow of the fire.
column3: Let's go up. And he snapped off the electric light, leaving only the rosy glow of the fire.

column2: Did you speak to Roscoe? she yawned, rising lopsidedly in her drowsiness.
column3: Did you speak to Roscoe? she yawned, rising lopsidedly in her drowsiness.

column2: Did you mention about what I told you the other evening?
column3: Did you mention about what I told you the other evening?

column2: No.	no
column3: false

column2: I will to-morrow."
column3: I will to morrow."

column2: But Roscoe did not come down-town the next day, nor the next; nor did Sheridan see fit to enter his son's house.
column3: But Roscoe did not come down town the next day, nor the next; nor did Sheridan see fit to enter his son's house.

column2: He waited.
column3: He waited.

column2: Then, on the fourth day of the month, Roscoe walked into his father's office at nine in the morning, when Sheridan happened to be alone.
column3: Then, on the fourth day of the month, Roscoe walked into his father's office at nine in the morning, when Sheridan happened to be alone.

column2: They told me down-stairs you'd left word you wanted to see me.
column3: They told me down stairs you'd left word you wanted to see me.

column2: Sit down, said Sheridan, rising.
column3: Sit down, said Sheridan, rising.

column2: Roscoe sat.
column3: Roscoe sat

column2: His father walked close to him, sniffed suspiciously, and then walked away, smiling bitterly.
column3: His father walked close to him, sniffed suspiciously, and then walked away, smiling bitterly.

column2: Boh! he exclaimed.
column3: Boh! he exclaimed.

column2: Still at it!
column3: Still at it!

column2: Yes, said Roscoe.
column3: Yes, said Roscoe.

column2: I've had a couple of drinks this morning.	I've had a couple of drinks this morning.
column3: false

column2: What about it?"
column3: What about it?"

column2: I reckon I better adopt some decent young man, his father returned. "I'd bring Bibbs up here and put him in your place if he was fit.
column3: I reckon I better adopt some decent young man, his father returned. "I'd bring Bibbs up here and put him in your place if he was fit.

column2: I would!"
column3: I would!"

column2: Better do it, Roscoe assented, sullenly.
column3: Better do it, Roscoe assented, sullenly.

column2: When'd you begin this thing?
column3: When'd you begin this thing?

column2: I always did drink a little.	I always did drink a little.
column3: true

column2: Ever since I grew up, that is."
column3: Ever since I grew up, that is."

column2: Leave that talk out!	Leave that talk out!
column3: true

column2: You know what I mean."
column3: You know what I mean."

column2: Well, I don't know as I ever had too much in office hours--until the other day.
column3: Well, I don't know as I ever had too much in office hours-until the other day.

column2: Sheridan began cutting.
column3: Sheridan began cutting.

column2: It's a lie.	It's a lie.
column3: false

column2: I've had Ray Wills up from your office.
column3: I've had Ray Wills up from your office.

column2: He didn't want to give you away, but I put the hooks into him, and he came through.
column3: He didn't want to give you away, but I put the hooks into him, and he came through.

column2: You were drunk twice before and couldn't work.
column3: You were drunk twice before and couldn't work.

column2: You been leavin' your office for drinks every few hours for the last three weeks.
column3: You been leavin' your office for drinks every few hours for the last three weeks.

column2: I been over your books.
column3: I been over your books.

column2: Your office is way behind.
column3: Your office is way behind.

column2: You haven't done any work, to count, in a month."
column3: You haven't done any work, to count, in a month."

column2: All right, said Roscoe, drooping under the torture.
column3: All right, said Roscoe, drooping under the torture.

column2: It's all true.
column3: It's all true.

column2: What you goin' to do about it?
column3: What you goin' to do about it?

column2: Roscoe's head was sunk between his shoulders.
column3: Roscoe's head was sunk between his shoulders.

column2: I can't stand very much talk about it, father, he said, pleadingly.
column3: I can't stand very much talk about it, father, he said, pleadingly.

column2: No! Sheridan cried.
column3: No! Sheridan cried.

column2: Neither can I! What do you think it means to ME? He dropped into the chair at his big desk, groaning.
column3: Neither can I! What do you think it means to m e? He dropped into the chair at his big desk, groaning.

column2: I can't stand to talk about it any more'n you can to listen, but I'm goin' to find out what's the matter with you, and I'm goin' to straighten you out!
column3: I can't stand to talk about it any more'n you can to listen, but I'm goin' to find out what's the matter with you, and I'm goin' to straighten you out!

column2: Roscoe shook his head helplessly.
column3: Roscoe shook his head helplessly.

column2: You can't straighten me out.
column3: You can't straighten me out.

column2: See here! said Sheridan.
column3: See here! said Sheridan.

column2: Can you go back to your office and stay sober to-day, while I get my work done, or will I have to hire a couple o' huskies to follow you around and knock the whiskey out o' your hand if they see you tryin' to take it?
column3: Can you go back to your office and stay sober to day, while I get my work done, or will I have to hire a couple o' huskies to follow you around and knock the whiskey out o' your hand if they see you tryin' to take it?

column2: You needn't worry about that, said Roscoe, looking up with a faint resentment.
column3: You needn't worry about that, said Roscoe, looking up with a faint resentment.

column2: I'm not drinking because I've got a thirst.
column3: I'm not drinking because I've got a thirst.

column2: Well, what have you got?
column3: Well, what have you got?

column2: Nothing.	Nothing.
column3: true

column2: Nothing you can do anything about.
column3: Nothing you can do anything about.

column2: Nothing, I tell you."
column3: Nothing, I tell you."

column2: We'll see about that! said Sheridan, harshly.
column3: We'll see about that! said Sheridan, harshly.

column2: Now I can't fool with you to-day, and you get up out o' that chair and get out o' my office.	Now I can't fool with you to day, and you get up out o' that chair and get out o' my office.
column3: false

column2: You bring your wife to dinner to-morrow.
column3: You bring your wife to dinner to morrow.

column2: You didn't come last Sunday--but you come to-morrow.
column3: You didn't come last Sunday-but you come to morrow.

column2: I'll talk this out with you when the women-folks are workin' the phonograph, after dinner.
column3: I'll talk this out with you when the women folks are workin' the phonograph, after dinner.

column2: Can you keep sober till then?
column3: Can you keep sober till then?

column2: You better be sure, because I'm going to send Abercrombie down to your office every little while, and he'll let me know."
column3: You better be sure, because I'm going to send Abercrombie down to your office every little while, and he'll let me know."

column2: Roscoe paused at the door.
column3: Roscoe paused at the door.

column2: You told Abercrombie about it? he asked.
column3: You told Abercrombie about it? he asked.

column2: TOLD him! And Sheridan laughed hideously.
column3: TOLD him! And Sheridan laughed hideously.

column2: Do you suppose there's an elevator-boy in the whole dam' building that ain't on to you?
column3: Do you suppose there's an elevator boy in the whole dam' building that ain't on to you?

column2: Roscoe settled his hat down over his eyes and went out.
column3: Roscoe settled his hat down over his eyes and went out.
